name: tris(trimethylsilyl)phosphine
Reason: The basic unit to consider is phosphine (PH3), which has a melting point of -133.5°C. Adding trimethylsilyl groups to phosphine will have several effects that influence the melting point. These effects include: 1) increased molecular weight due to the addition of trimethylsilyl groups, which tends to increase the melting point, and 2) increased steric hindrance and bulkiness, which may lead to a less efficient crystal packing, potentially reducing the melting point. A quantity for each trimethylsilyl group must be estimated. Each trimethylsilyl (TMS) group will raise the melting point. Estimating conservatively, each TMS group may add approximately 50-60°C; this is because TMS groups are bulky, leading to inefficient packing, so the effect is less than for smaller groups. With three TMS groups attached, one can estimate a total increase of 150-180°C. Thus, the predicted melting point would be -133.5 + 150 to -133.5 + 180°C.
